Award.AwardTitle: SAVI: Building a framework between the EU and the USA to harmonize data products relevant to global research infrastructures in the environmental field
Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Collaborative Research: SAVI- Building a framework between the EU and the USA to harmonize data products relevant to global research infrastructures in the environmental field.

This award is designated as a Science Across Virtual Institutes (SAVI) award and is co-funded by NSF's Office of International and Integrative Activities. Four U.S. environmental observatories (National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON), Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI), Advanced Modular Incoherent Scatter Radar (AMISR) and collectively EarthScope, comprising USArray and the Plate Boundary Observatory (PBO), operated respectively by the Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology (IRIS) and UNAVCO) are working together with their respective counterparts from the European Union on developing common data policies and standards relevant to global research infrastructures in the environment field.

The project goals include developing new understanding through broad harmonization of data and constructing multi- discipline, synergistic data products that have wider societal importance. In addition, these activities will help the scientific community to better develop coupled models that better capture critical feedbacks and interactions of the earth system. These models are needed to help make these types of data more accessible to decision-makers at many levels.

Linking these existing programs provides a unique opportunity for early career researchers and students to learn in a multi-disciplinary environment and to benefit not only from the U.S. participants but also their European counterparts. The observatories will be developing graduate and post-graduate courses and the workshops will seek to include early career scientists and students.

The proposed activities will focus on addressing societally relevant challenges. Through case studies, ways of harmonizing data will be investigated with the goal of making the data from these observatories easier to include in effective decision-making. Disasters, carbon and water will likely be the first set of issues addressed.

This program is creating opportunities for enhancing the career trajectories of a new generation of researchers in Europe and the U.S. The virtual institute is providing mechanisms for exposing early-career scientists to interdisciplinary, multi-institutional activities focused on environmental data and cyberinfrastructure; arming them with new scientific tools to address challenging questions in harmonizing environmental data to help in effective decision making; and showing them how international partnerships can help to solve global problems. It is recruiting a diverse set of U.S. and European students to create collaborative networks of environmental data and cyberinfrastructure experts across these countries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal goal of CoopEUS was to identify the barriers and activities to make data interoperable from one large-scale Environmental Research Infrastructures (ERI) to another.  In this way, we increase our ability to transfer information into new knowledge, expand scientific discovery, and advance transformative science.  We did this by bringing together ERIs in carbon, biodiversity, space weather, geodesy and seismology, and ocean sciences from the United States and Europe.  This project leveraged the original NSF investments in these ERIs.  First, we i) established an international governance structure, ii) broadly surveyed and assessed the needs and knowledge gaps that can inform 'data interoperability', that in turn, iii) developed a joint implementation plan (roadmap) [https://www.coopeus.eu/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/D8.3-DRAFT-COOPEUS_roadmap_D8.3.pdf]

 The US ERIs were:

National Ecological Observatory Network [neonscience.org]

University NAVSTAR Consortium [unavco.org]

Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology [www.iris.edu/hq/]

Advanced Modular Incoherent Scatter Radar [amisr.com/amisr/] 

Ocean Observatories Initiative [oceanobservatories.org/]

 

The EU ERIs were:

Integrated Carbon Observing System [https://www.icos-ri.eu/]

European Multidisciplinary Seafloor Observatory [emso.eu]

European Plate Observing System  [epos-ip.org]

European incoherent scatter radar [www.eiscat.se/]

LifeWatch [http://www.lifewatch.eu/]

Since this original suite of ERIs began this effort, numerous other ERIs also wished to join this project (e.g., Australia TERN, China CERN) and well as other related projects, e.g., ENVRI+, COOP+, FIERI)

 

We had to define 'interoperability' (or 'harmonization') in this scientific context, because it can mean different things to different projects.  Here, we defined 'interoperability' to advance scientific utility [Figure 1].   Having this definition allowed us to identify and prototype our efforts towards data interoperability.

 

Both the human and cultural capital was needed to build capacity towards building and using interoperable data.  Hence, we had to overcome the technical, scientific, cultural and geopolitical barriers to achieve 'scientific utility'. At the same time, the diverse cultures in CoopEUS partners brought additional resiliency to our approach.   

 

As part of CoopEUS, we hosted several workshops to bring together and train the next generation of users; i.e., three Carbon Users Workshops (CUW), and one Data Model Fusion Workshop (MDF).  The CUWs bought together early career scientists who use in-situ data to address emergent issues in ecosystem science.  The CUWs had a combined 69 international students or post-docs, and +68 internationally recognized instructors.  These multi-week-long courses addressed new research frontiers, linked theory and applications, and hypothesis testing.  The instructor to student ratio was 2:1. The MDF workshop brought together +20 renowned scientists to identify the barriers best to integrate 'large scale data' with advanced earth system modeling.  Our philosophy was always broad inclusion, these courses consisted were inclusive of gender diversity (female, male, other), career level and skillsets (advanced masters stuents, PhD students, post-docs), age, diversity of science disciplines and expertise, geographical distribution (China, US, Europe), and included underrepresented groups.  

 

We also prototyped our COOPEUS roadmap to inform lessons learned and to advance broader implementation, i.e.,

Prototype: Integrating Dynamic Workflows to Web Services (firemap.sdsc.edu/savi/map.html) This prototype advanced the harmonization/interoperability of data from RIs by combining dynamic workflow (Kepler) environment with research objects (ROs).  This approach facilitated reusability, version control, reproducibility (citable DOI), and sped computational time for 'Big Data' users.  Working with San Diego Supercomputing Center, this prototype combined data from UNAVCO and NEON using standardized web services in the GeoWS time series format. [Figure 2]

Prototype: Plant Phenological Ontology (PPO) Data (www.plantphenology.org/) The use of plant phenology data, the timing of life-cycle events such as flowering or leafing out, was initiated to increase the precision of productivity models by constraining the timing of these events with biophysical processes.  This prototype brought together plant phenological data (NEON, National Phenology Network (NPN), European Plant Phenotyping Network (EPPN), phenocams, etc.) and established a new dynamic ontology to facilitate data harmonization of sources.  This prototype crafted a global data portal that enables rapid searching over 20 million observations.  The effort currently resides with CyVerse (www.cyverse.org/). [Figure 3]

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2019
Modified by: Hank W Loescher

In this way, we increase our ability to transfer information into new knowledge, expand scientific discovery, and advance transformative science. We did this by bringing together ERIs in carbon, biodiversity, space weather, geodesy and seismology, and ocean sciences from the United States and Europe. This project leveraged the original NSF investments in these ERIs. First, we i) established an international governance structure, ii) broadly surveyed and assessed the needs and knowledge gaps that can inform 'data interoperability', that in turn, iii) developed a joint implementation plan (roadmap) [https://www.coopeus.eu/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/D8.3-DRAFT-COOPEUS_roadmap_D8.3.pdf] The US ERIs were: National Ecological Observatory Network [neonscience.org] University NAVSTAR Consortium [unavco.org] Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology [www.iris.edu/hq/] Advanced Modular Incoherent Scatter Radar [amisr.com/amisr/] Ocean Observatories Initiative [oceanobservatories.org/] The EU ERIs were: Integrated Carbon Observing System [https://www.icos-ri.eu/] European Multidisciplinary Seafloor Observatory [emso.eu] European Plate Observing System [epos-ip.org] European incoherent scatter radar [www.eiscat.se/] LifeWatch [http://www.lifewatch.eu/] Since this original suite of ERIs began this effort, numerous other ERIs also wished to join this project (e.g., Australia TERN, China CERN) and well as other related projects, e.g., ENVRI+, COOP+, FIERI) We had to define 'interoperability' (or 'harmonization') in this scientific context, because it can mean different things to different projects. Here, we defined 'interoperability' to advance scientific utility [Figure 1]. Having this definition allowed us to identify and prototype our efforts towards data interoperability. Both the human and cultural capital was needed to build capacity towards building and using interoperable data. Hence, we had to overcome the technical, scientific, cultural and geopolitical barriers to achieve 'scientific utility'. At the same time, the diverse cultures in CoopEUS partners brought additional resiliency to our approach. As part of CoopEUS, we hosted several workshops to bring together and train the next generation of users; i.e., three Carbon Users Workshops (CUW), and one Data Model Fusion Workshop (MDF). The CUWs bought together early career scientists who use in-situ data to address emergent issues in ecosystem science. The CUWs had a combined 69 international students or post-docs, and +68 internationally recognized instructors. These multi-week-long courses addressed new research frontiers, linked theory and applications, and hypothesis testing. The instructor to student ratio was 2:1. The MDF workshop brought together +20 renowned scientists to identify the barriers best to integrate 'large scale data' with advanced earth system modeling. Our philosophy was always broad inclusion, these courses consisted were inclusive of gender diversity (female, male, other), career level and skillsets (advanced masters stuents, PhD students, post-docs), age, diversity of science disciplines and expertise, geographical distribution (China, US, Europe), and included underrepresented groups. We also prototyped our COOPEUS roadmap to inform lessons learned and to advance broader implementation, i.e., Prototype: Integrating Dynamic Workflows to Web Services (firemap.sdsc.edu/savi/map.html) This prototype advanced the harmonization/interoperability of data from RIs by combining dynamic workflow (Kepler) environment with research objects (ROs). This approach facilitated reusability, version control, reproducibility (citable DOI), and sped computational time for 'Big Data' users. Working with San Diego Supercomputing Center, this prototype combined data from UNAVCO and NEON using standardized web services in the GeoWS time series format. [Figure 2] Prototype: Plant Phenological Ontology (PPO) Data (www.plantphenology.org/) The use of plant phenology data, the timing of life-cycle events such as flowering or leafing out, was initiated to increase the precision of productivity models by constraining the timing of these events with biophysical processes. This prototype brought together plant phenological data (NEON, National Phenology Network (NPN), European Plant Phenotyping Network (EPPN), phenocams, etc.) and established a new dynamic ontology to facilitate data harmonization of sources. This prototype crafted a global data portal that enables rapid searching over 20 million observations. The effort currently resides with CyVerse (www.cyverse.org/).
